title: Domain 5.1: Summarize elements of effective security governance.
content:
Provide broad principles or best practices—used to guide decisions and behavior within the organization.

📜 Policies

📄 Acceptable Use Policy (AUP)

Defines what employees are allowed to do with company resources (e.g., email, internet)—helps prevent misuse.

🔒 Information Security Policies

High-level rules governing how the organization protects its data, assets, and operations.

🏢 Business Continuity

Ensures critical business functions can continue during and after a disaster or disruption.

🌪️ Disaster Recovery

Detailed plans to restore systems and data after a catastrophic event (e.g., ransomware, natural disasters).

🚨 Incident Response

Procedures for detecting, responding to, and recovering from security incidents (e.g., data breaches, attacks).

🖥️ Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC)

Security-integrated processes for developing secure software—from design to deployment.

🔄 Change Management

Ensures that changes (software, hardware, processes) are made in a controlled, secure, and documented manner.

🏅 Standards

🔑 Password

Guidelines for creating strong passwords—length, complexity, expiration, and multi-factor authentication (MFA).

🔒 Access Control

Defines who can access which resources and at what level—critical for least privilege and securing sensitive data.

🏢 Physical Security

Measures to prevent unauthorized physical access to facilities or hardware (e.g., locks, guards).

🔑 Encryption

Protects data confidentiality both at rest and in transit—ensures sensitive information remains unreadable to unauthorized parties.

🛠️ Procedures

🔄 Change Management

A structured approach to ensure that changes (technical, operational) are implemented without compromising security or stability.

🧑‍💻 Onboarding/Offboarding

Securely adding new employees to systems and removing access when employees leave—ensures no lingering or unauthorized access.

📚 Playbooks

Predefined, step-by-step procedures for responding to various security incidents—helps ensure consistent, fast responses.

🌍 External Considerations

🏛️ Regulatory

Industry-specific laws and regulations (e.g., GDPR, HIPAA) that dictate data protection and security requirements.

⚖️ Legal

Legal obligations and frameworks surrounding data handling, privacy, and security incidents.

🏭 Industry

Best practices and standards specific to an industry—can include sector-specific regulations or certifications.

🌎 Local/Regional

Laws and security practices that vary by geography—important for multinational operations.

🇺🇸 National

Country-specific regulations (e.g., FISMA in the U.S.) that apply to all organizations operating within that country.

🌐 Global

International standards and treaties affecting global operations and cross-border data flows (e.g., GDPR).

🧐 Monitoring and Revision

Continuously track, evaluate, and update security policies and controls to adapt to evolving threats and organizational needs.

🏛️ Types of Governance Structures

🏢 Boards

Senior-level governance group responsible for overseeing high-level security policies and compliance.

🏫 Committees

Groups focused on specific security topics, such as incident response or compliance—help with in-depth management.

🏛️ Government Entities

Regulatory and compliance bodies that enforce national security standards and laws (e.g., NIST, ISO).

⚖️ Centralized/Decentralized

Centralized: One central authority enforces policies. Decentralized: Multiple units share governance responsibilities with flexibility.

🧑‍💻 Roles and Responsibilities for Systems and Data

👤 Owners

Individuals or entities responsible for the security and integrity of systems or data.

📝 Controllers

Organizations that determine the purposes and means of processing personal data—have direct responsibility for compliance.

🖥️ Processors

Entities that process data on behalf of the controller—have limited responsibilities related to data security.

🛡️ Custodians/Stewards

Individuals responsible for day-to-day management, safeguarding, and handling of systems or data.
